column4: Koobalito: That depends on what you want out of your system, and how much tweaking you are up for.
Then I guess Ubuntu is a good place to start, koobalito =)
KM201: but can't you see how that feature would be a pro to a new comer?
KM201: Hm, interesting point.
koobalita, oh cool. Didn't get that.
I have a question. Why isn't VLC on Ubuntu by standard? It's much more popular (atleast I think so) and IMO better than the random movie players we get by default.
Monkeydust: wat
Totem is part of of the GNOME desktop environment.
Use it on the first archive of the series and it should extract from all of them.
I remeber someone here saying recently that it doesn't do globbing for some reason.
ok, so how do I solve it?
Something like; find . -maxdepth 1 -iname "*.rar" -exec unrar {} \;
that just listed all of the options..
sorry, I missed the argument for unraring something. Its unrar x {]  I think.
ok, so "find . -maxdepth 1 -iname "*.rar" -exec unrar x {} \;"? Do I need the " in front of *.rar?
yes.
You can always test it by using -echo ranther than -exec to see what commands it would have issued :)
find /path/ -type d -iname "sample" -delete
thans man, you really seem to be an expert =)
should I replace the /path/ part? I am writing a script, and I want to delete the sample dir in the folder I'm activating the script from
Replace /path/ with wherever you want to start searching from/ use . for current directory.
no. It becomes:  .
find . -etc etc
hehe ok =)
